moves.1. c4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 c5: In the 2nd Game if the 1966 match Spassky played 3...Be7 and went in for the Tartakover Variation of the Orthodox Defence.
moves.4. cxd5 exd5 5. Nf3 Nc6 6. g3: At the moment, Spassky and Petrosian are showing that they are great strategists.
moves.6... Nf6 7. Bg2 Be7 8. O-O O-O 9. Bg5 cx: This game, so far, is being played the exact same way that it did when Spassky played Korchnoi an another championship match!!!
moves.12... Be6 13. Rc1 Re8 14. Nb5 Qd7 15. Nb: It is preffered to play 15. Bc5. It is much more sturdier move.
This knight's job is to neutralize its opposite number.
moves.20... Qb7 21. Kg1: It took a very long time for Petrosian to decide this move.
moves.21... Rac8 22. Rfc1 Nd7 23. Nf3 c5 24. b: Spassky has the freer game and is therefore right to start probing white's resistance.
moves.31. Nd2 Nxd2 32. Bxd2 Qa6 33. Kf1: If white was not careful, he could have fallen into a nasty trap. Can you see it?
moves.38. h3 Bd6 39. Qd3 Be5: I really don't think that the 2 GMs should sacrifice their bishops. I do not know why.
moves.40. Bxe5 Qxe5: At the moment, Spassky is winning on position, but white can pose a threat.
moves.41. h4 Kf8 42. Kf1 Ke7 43. Kf2 Qe6 44. Q: This is to stop the king from getting to the queenside.
moves.48. bxc4 dxc4 49. Qc3+ Ke6 50. Ke3: White does not need to worry about a pawn ending.
And so both players decide on a draw.

Thank you for watching this breath-taking match, and goodbye :)
